skill.name: requirements-elicitation
skill.description: Requirements gathering and elicitation techniques for business analysis. Use when conducting stakeholder interviews, gathering functional/non-functional requirements, or identifying gaps in requirements.
skill.summary: Requirements gathering and elicitation techniques for business analysis. Use when conducting stakeho...
skill.author: DoubleslashSE

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only structured question templates and guidance for requirements gathering. No executable code, no file access, no network activity, and no command execution capabilities. The skill poses zero security risk to users.

content.value_statement: Poor requirements lead to project failures and wasted development effort. This skill provides structured question templates and techniques to systematically gather complete, unambiguous requirements from stakeholders through proven elicitation methods.
actual_capabilities: Guide stakeholder interviews using structured question templates organized by category
Apply FURPS+ model to gather non-functional requirements (performance, security, usability)
Use MoSCoW method and value-effort matrix for requirement prioritization
Identify functional and non-functional requirements with SMART criteria validation
Conduct gap analysis between current and desired system states
Generate stakeholder maps with influence and interest level analysis
limitations: Does not execute code or access external systems to automatically extract requirements
Does not generate formal requirement documents in specific organizational formats
Does not integrate with project management tools to create tickets automatically

use_cases.title: Conduct stakeholder interviews
use_cases.description: Use structured question templates to gather complete requirements from stakeholders during discovery phase.

use_cases.title: Define MVP scope
use_cases.description: Apply prioritization techniques to identify must-have features for minimum viable product releases.

use_cases.title: Validate requirements quality
use_cases.description: Check gathered requirements against SMART and INVEST criteria before development begins.

prompt_templates.title: Basic interview start
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me conduct a requirements gathering interview. The stakeholder is [role] and we are discussing [project]. Start with open-ended questions to understand their needs.

prompt_templates.title: Functional requirements
prompt_templates.prompt: What are the main functional requirements for [system]? Ask me about user actions, data processing, business rules, and expected outputs.

prompt_templates.title: Non-functional requirements
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me gather non-functional requirements using the FURPS+ model. Ask me about performance, security, usability, reliability, and supportability needs.

prompt_templates.title: Prioritization workshop
prompt_templates.prompt: We have gathered [list requirements]. Help me apply the MoSCoW method to prioritize each one as Must Have, Should Have, Could Have, or Won't Have.

output_examples.input: Help me gather requirements for a new customer portal from the marketing team.
output: Functional Requirements: User registration, profile management, content access, communication preferences
Non-Functional Requirements: 99.9% uptime, page load under 3 seconds, GDPR compliance
Priority: Must Have - User registration, profile management
Stakeholder concerns: Data privacy, brand consistency

best_practices: Start interviews with open-ended questions before moving to specific details
Validate understanding by summarizing requirements back to stakeholders
Use follow-up patterns (specific examples, break down complexity) when answers are vague or incomplete
anti_patterns: Asking leading questions that suggest expected answers
Skipping validation questions to confirm understanding
Accepting requirements without checking for ambiguity or conflicts

faq.question: What tools does this skill work with?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. It provides guidance and templates rather than direct tool integration.

faq.question: How many questions should I ask in one session?
faq.answer: Plan for 60-90 minutes per stakeholder category. Break longer interviews into multiple sessions to avoid stakeholder fatigue.

faq.question: Can I customize the question templates?
faq.answer: Yes. The templates are starting points. Adjust questions based on stakeholder domain knowledge and project context.

faq.question: Is my interview data stored anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This skill only provides guidance. All interview data remains in your conversation with the AI assistant.

faq.question: Why use FURPS+ instead of other NFR frameworks?
faq.answer: FURPS+ provides a comprehensive checklist covering Functionality, Usability, Reliability, Performance, Supportability, and constraints.

faq.question: How does this differ from requirements management tools?
faq.answer: This skill guides the elicitation process. Requirements management tools organize and track requirements after they are gathered.
